docs.abstract: Dr Mitchell Rubin letter on December 23 article on rise of diabetes in America describes doctor's poor eating habits at medical conference (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re the Personal Health column ''Stampede of Diabetes as U.S. Races to Obesity'' (Dec. 23): With the epidemic of obesity and its dreaded consequences upon us, national eating habits must change. It would seem logical that certain segments of our society are already enlightened. But while recently attending an important medical conference, I was horrified to see throngs of physicians heartily eating muffins, cakes and supersized doughnuts for breakfast.

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration recently announced ban on sale of ephedra, weight-loss drug, after review of 16,000 reports of adverse reactions, including death; drug has been only effective over-the-counter supplement for weight loss and ban, although supported by medical community, leaves ephedra users without comparable alternative; prescription and non-prescription alternatives for ephedra discussed; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Now that ephedra is to be banned, the millions of people who have been taking the supplement to lose weight or control it may find themselves looking for an alternative. But weight-loss and nutrition experts nationwide say that no other over-the-counter supplements advertised as weight-loss aids are as effective as ephedra. ''I'm not pushing ephedra, and I wouldn't recommend it to anybody, but several very good studies have shown that ephedra combined with caffeine promotes weight loss,'' said Dr. Ken Fujioka, director of the Nutrition and Metabolic Research Center at the Scripps Clinic in San Diego. ''I don't know of any other over-the-counter preparation that has shown that kind of consistent effect.''

docs.abstract: American Academy of Pediatrics says soft drinks should be eliminated from schools to help tackle nation's obesity epidemic (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Soft drinks should be eliminated from schools to help tackle the nation's obesity epidemic, the American Academy of Pediatrics says. In a new policy statement, the academy says that pediatricians should contact local superintendents and school board members and ''emphasize the notion that every school in every district shares a responsibility for the nutritional health of its students.''
